title: Dialogues in Real Analysis

1 Welcome
This book presents Real Analysis concepts through dialogues between Lila (the student) and Acharya Bhaskara (the teacher).
The style is conversational, but the mathematics is rigorous.

text:
3 ğŸ“– Dialogue: Why Real Numbers?
Lila:
â€œAcharya, we already have natural numbers, integers, rationals. Why do we need real numbers? Arenâ€™t rationals enough?â€
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œThat is a wise question, Lila. Let us test the rationals. Can you think of a number whose square is 2?â€
Lila:
â€œWellâ€¦ if I try,
- \[1.4^2 = 1.96\],
- \[1.41^2 = 1.9881\],
- \[1.414^2 = 1.999396\]â€¦
We get closer, but never exactly 2.â€
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œSo, do you think there is a rational number \[q\] with \[q^2 = 2\]?â€
Lila:
â€œNo.Â Iâ€™ve seen the proof that \[\sqrt{2}\] is irrational.â€
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œCorrect. But notice this: even if \[\sqrt{2}\] is not rational, we can approximate it as closely as we like using rationals â€” 1.4, 1.41, 1.414â€¦ The rationals are dense: between any two rationals, there is another. Yet something is still missing.â€

title: 2Â  Dialogue: Why Real Numbers?
text:
3.1 ğŸ”¹ Bounds
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œLet us capture this rigorously. Consider the set
\[ S = \{ x \in \mathbb{Q} : x^2 < 2 \}. \]
Is there a number that is always greater than every element of this set?â€
Lila:
â€œSure, 2 is bigger than all of them. So is 1.5, or 1.42.â€
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œExactly. We call such numbers upper bounds. But among them, some are tighter than others. Which number feels like the â€˜tightestâ€™ upper bound?â€
Lila:
â€œIt should be \[\sqrt{2}\], since thatâ€™s where the set stops.â€
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œIndeed. But here is the problem: \[\sqrt{2}\] is not in \[\mathbb{Q}\]. So the rationals cannot capture the least upper bound of this set.â€

title: 2Â  Dialogue: Why Real Numbers?
text:
3.2 ğŸ”¹ Supremum
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œThis brings us to a definition:

An upper bound of a set \[A \subset \mathbb{R}\] is a number \[M\] such that \[x \leq M\] for all \[x \in A\].

The least upper bound (also called the supremum) is the smallest such \[M\], if it exists.â€

Lila:
â€œSo the problem with rationals is that some sets donâ€™t have a supremum inside them?â€
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œPrecisely. The rationals are dense but incomplete. The missing piece is the completeness property of the reals.â€

title: 2Â  Dialogue: Why Real Numbers?
text:
3.3 ğŸ”¹ Completeness Axiom
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œThe defining property of the real numbers is this:

Completeness Axiom: Every nonempty set of real numbers that is bounded above has a least upper bound (supremum) in \[\mathbb{R}\].

This axiom is what makes the real line whole.â€

title: 2Â  Dialogue: Why Real Numbers?
text:
3.4 ğŸ”¹ Returning to \[S\]
Lila:
â€œSo for \[S = \{ x : x^2 < 2 \}\], the supremum is \[\sqrt{2}\], which does exist in \[\mathbb{R}\].â€
Acharya Bhaskara:
â€œExactly. And that, Lila, is the difference between rationals and reals. Completeness fills the gaps and makes the real line continuous. Without it, calculus itself would crumble.â€
